header_summary:
The release of Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc2, a critical step towards finalizing the software's next major update, has been announced, with binaries available for testing on [Bitcoin Core's official site](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc2/). This version, aimed at refining the platform, invites community feedback through its [GitHub issues page](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/33368), and detailed insights into the changes can be found in the preliminary release notes and testing guide linked on the Bitcoin Core DevWiki.

ZmnSCPxj et al. delve into the cryptographic enhancement of blockchain security through the restructuring of quorum signing groups, introducing a methodology that flattens nested quorum structures into a more streamlined, single-layer configuration to ensure the indispensable participation of a single signer. This conceptual advancement, significant for its potential to simplify complex signing processes and bolster security across various blockchain applications including the Lightning Network, is further elaborated with practical examples and implications for hardware wallet security, as documented on [Delving Bitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/flattening-nested-2-of-2-of-a-1-of-1-and-a-k-of-n/2018).

The scalability challenges facing blockchain technology, particularly the pragmatic issue of node data pruning versus the need for complete historical transaction data, are scrutinized by garlonicon. The discussion highlights the necessity for innovative data management solutions to sustain the decentralized nature of blockchain networks while accommodating growing storage demands, suggesting the exploration of new strategies that could enable efficient, trustless synchronization of blockchain data from pruned nodes without compromising decentralization, as seen in discussions on [Delving Bitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/limiting-op-return-at-consensus-level/2013/4).

Lastly, ZmnSCPxj introduces a novel transaction management approach utilizing a pseudo-Spilman scheme and single-use-seals to enhance the security and efficiency of blockchain transactions. This method emphasizes reduced reliance on mutual trust among participants, leveraging blockchain scripting capabilities to secure transactions unilaterally, thereby offering a promising avenue for mitigating risks associated with transaction relays and promoting a more secure, high-availability network environment as discussed on [Delving Bitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/multichannel-and-multiptlc-towards-a-global-high-availability-consistent-partition-tolerant-database-for-bitcoin-payments/1983/12).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0rc2 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc2 binaries are now available for testing purposes.
- Details and a testing guide for this release can be viewed on their official site and GitHub.
- If no critical issues are found, v30.0rc2 will advance as the official v30.0 release.

recent_posts.title: Flattening Nested 2-of-2 Of a 1-of-1 And a k-of-n
recent_posts.summary:
- The concept of converting nested quorum groups into a single-layer for enhanced security is explored.
- Examples include turning a 2-of-3 group into a 4-of-5 setup, ensuring essential participation.
- Real-world applications, security concerns, and further reading on cryptographic security are discussed.

recent_posts.title: Limiting OP_RETURN at consensus level
recent_posts.summary:
- Blockchain scalability issues prompt a reevaluation of node's role in data storage.
- Pruning practices save space but challenge the network's historical data accessibility.
- Innovations are needed for efficient, decentralized blockchain data management and access.

recent_posts.title: MultiChannel and MultiPTLC: Towards A Global High-Availability Consistent/Partition-Tolerant Database For Bitcoin Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal explores a pseudo-Spilman scheme for blockchain transactions, reducing the k-of-n trust requirement.
- It introduces a chaining method for transactions and a Decker-Russel-Osuntokun mechanism for enhanced security.
- The aim is a less trust-dependent, more secure, and efficient blockchain transaction environment.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts
authors: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts Aiden McClelland
active_posts.summary:
- Aiden McClelland proposed a modular mempool/relay policy BIP, inviting community review.
- The proposal aims to resolve Bitcoin's relay policy conflicts without requiring forks.
- Despite programming challenges, McClelland is developing a reference implementation using QuickJS.

active_posts.title: [0/4] A Bitcoin Scripting Proposal BIP Quartet
active_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell and Julian Moik aim to enhance Bitcoin's scripting language to its original potential.
- Their draft proposes a variable operations budget and the reactivation of disabled opcodes.
- Innovations include a new opcode for data introspection and additional opcodes for Tapscript v2.

active_posts.title: Re: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts]
active_posts.summary:
- The email discusses Bitcoin's scalability, highlighting the critical role of nodes and consensus rules.
- It touches on conflicts between mempool and miner policies, emphasizing the need to maintain network health.
- Proposes consensus-ban on dust transactions as a solution to preserve decentralization and manage operational costs.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 updates enhance Bitcoin's defense against quantum threats by adopting P2QRH within taproot.
- The shift to script-only versions removes quantum-vulnerable paths, increasing attack resilience.
- It also outlines a plan for future Post-Quantum signature integration, avoiding premature commitments.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's fee estimation process is complex and uncertain due to miner unpredictability.
- Efforts to standardize mempools may lead to harmful centralization and increased censorship risks.
- The critique advises focusing on broad heuristics and adapting to transaction process variabilities.

active_posts.title: Stealth addresses using nostr
active_posts.summary:
- Nostr uses Bitcoin's cryptographic techniques for key generation and receiving payments.
- It introduces a way to improve user experience by notifying users of payments with encrypted messages.
- The article provides a proof of concept with Python code for creating and using stealth keys in Nostr.

today_in_history_posts.title: Test cases for Taproot signature message
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A pull request for BIPs repository on GitHub was opened by Giacomo Caironi.
- Discussion on bitcoin-dev mailing list led to acknowledging unclear Taproot documentation.
- Wuille supported Caironi's initiative to improve Taproot test cases and integration.
contributors: [bitcoin-dev] Test cases for Taproot signature message Giacomo Caironi

today_in_history_posts.title: Lightning over taproot with PTLCs
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The Lightning Network's protocol update involves replacing BOLT#2 and BOLT#3 with a PTLC-focused proposal.
- This proposal aims to reduce data storage, latency, on-chain footprint, and prevent third-party analysis.
- It includes features like HTLC support, musig and musig2 for key operations, and a structure for various transaction layers.

today_in_history_posts.title: Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- In March 2024, a btcd consensus bug was found and fixed in version 0.24.2.
- The bug allowed for potential hard forking of btcd nodes, prompting urgent upgrades.
- Despite minor network impact, transparency and prompt upgrade to v0.24.2 are emphasized.
